content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is easy to solve

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think the main difficulty is to find the non-numbers part. But when you get it, extract the numbers is easier. Maybe a little difficult to code in less than 5 minutes, but i think it's feasible.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: manipulation de string intéressante, où il faut faire attention à plusieurs détails. Pas facile de finir en 5 minutes si on est pas habitué à un langage qui gère bien les string mais faisable

It took me less than 5 minutes to solve. Here is the code (in python):
import re
total = 0
for match in re.finditer(r'(-?\d+)(\w+(\^\d)?)', input()):
    total += int(match[1])
    suffix = match[2]
print(str(total) + suffix)
However, it assumes that all terms have same letters and exponents (what is ok for this puzzle). Minified version of my code (for shortest mode) has 102 characters.

typos in the statement:
Harry have discover letters -> Harry *has discovered* letters
His teacher tels the class -> His teacher *tells* the class
a program that automatically add/substract -> a program that automatically *adds/substracts*

This is a fun algebraic expression parsing problem.  Gather the variables, constants, exponents, coefficients, and arithmetic operations and then simplify the expression.  You lose the value of the problem if you simplify it enough for a clash.  Make it an easy problem instead.  You could even add back in multiplication and division as well as constants and multiple variables. Perhaps even having a Easy and Hard version of the problem.

Also you would need to rewrite the statement fixing English errors.  When you make it a harder problem, you will need to provide how you want the terms of the expression ordered in the output.

Ok, it's my first puzzle, i don't really know how to estimate the difficulty. 

My first idea was to be able to handle multiplication as "4x*5b=20bx" or "4x*5x=20x^2" but i was already blocked by the time so i reduced to only sums... 

I'll think about reducing the puzzle
Well... formal calculus can be seen in computer science as all the methods allowing to do algebra on a computer.
Isn't this just algebra instead of calculus (differentiation and integration)? Thanks.
I agree ! Too long to be coded in 15 minutes following the edge cases
the first version included multiplication and non-reductible expression but it was really hard to solve in less than 5min.
You should submit your first version as a solo puzzle, i think it can be helpful to learn about string manipulation.
I've made some change : i only ask to add/substract the terms that are given in the input. Without any comparaison, it's seems easier to do no ?
